children.subject: I did not notice this. Thanks!
I can't speak to the other classes you've mentioned, but 176 is also only offered in the fall if that helps.

history.content: Prof. Yosef, who taught CS176 this past semester, has posted a spreadsheet of all the relevant courses here. I think you will find it helpful.

children.subject: Aw, it sounded really interesting. From the other comment here, it seems like it might not be offered anytime soon. Thanks for letting me know!

I wouldn't take math 127 if I were you it was probably the most disorganised class I've taken at Berkeley. There was one homework the entire semester at week two which was never graded and your entire course grade depended on a term project which really just culminates in applying the fast Fourier transform and a final which we knew nothing about until we took it (there were no review sessions, practice exams, or even homeworks to go off of).

Thanks for your detailed response! I'm interested in the -omics section, but I also want to learn about eukaryotic/multicellular genetics over microbial genetics, so I have a hard time deciding between the two. I can just take both classes and use c148 as my elective, but then (a) I wouldn't be able to choose any other elective, (b) I don't have space to take another class, and (c) I'm not even that interested in genetics to take two genetics courses.

Why did you decide to take c148 over 140?

I didn't have a choice for my major--I had to take C148! But I definitely don't think there's any reason to take both, especially if you aren't super interested in genetics, since either will cover the fundamentals (which are the same for microbes/non-microbes). If I had to choose now, I think I'd still go with C148, since my research/overall interests are very microbiology-oriented, but I think both are good options.

As far as deciding between C148 and 140, I took C148 and really enjoyed it. The compbio module went over the basics of parsimony-based phylogeny and alignment algorithms (Smith-Waterman and Needleman-Wunsch). Because basically no one in the class has any CS background, the professor also spent awhile covering the basics of time complexity at a 61B sort of level. These topics are all covered again both more quickly and in more detail in 170/176, so depending on your perspective it's either a nice preview or redundant. There wasn't any programming at all. It is definitely entirely microbial (and specifically mostly prokaryotes) so you might be missing some details about eukaryotic/multicellular genetics, but I believe it goes into more detail about -omics techniques than 140 does, and I think if you're interested in compbio that could be useful to you too. It doesn't have biochem as a prereq, so there's probably less detail about pathways than you'd get in 140.

And re: Math 127, I enjoyed that class too and in retrospect I learned a lot, but I agree with the person above me that the class structure was very disorganized and it was pretty stressful at the time. Also, the professors who have taught the class in the past (David Dynerman and Lior Pachter) have both left Berkeley and there isn't really anyone in the math department left with a strong interest in mathematical biology, so I think there's a very high likelihood the class won't be offered again before you graduate :(
Does the math department website mention this somewhere? I cannot seem to find it.
Math 127 is not currently on the schedule for next year (2019-20).

history.content:
Hello! I am doing an MCB major and CS minor. I tentatively want to go into software development in the biology field once I graduate.

I am completely lost on how to cover all (or most) of all the compbio concepts covered in CS 176, Math 127, and MCB c148. I definitely want to take 176. I am considering taking Math 127 for my MCB elective and deciding between MCB c148 and MCB 140 for my genetics requirement.

Because of overlap between the courses, I am not sure whether I should take some or all of them. MCB c148 is a genetics course with a compbio component, so I am not sure if I should take MCB 140 instead and learn the compbio portion in 176/127. I am also leaning towards the latter option since 140 is general genetics, whereas c148 is microbial genetics.

From looking at the syllabi, it seems like CS 176 and Math 127 have some overlap (I saw some matching words), but I'm not exactly sure to what extent, so I am not sure if I should take Math 127 or another course instead for my elective.

Furthermore, Math 127 is not offered all semesters. This might play a role in planning out my courses for my last 3 semesters here.

My mind is just a complete mess and I have no idea what to do. Any MCB/CS people here that can help me sort things out? Thanks :)
history.subject: Compbio: CS 176, Math 127, MCB c148
